General Laws c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: General Laws c. 186, § 14 provides in relevant part that a landlord shall not “directly or indirectly interfere with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant,” and that any landlord who does so “shall… be liable for actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.”

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19\u201321.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in the Springfield District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19–21 and G.L. c. 223, § 2, because the Premises are located within this Court’s territorial jurisdiction and the causes of action arose here.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in the Springfield District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19–21 and G.L. c. 223, § 2, because the Premises are located within this Court’s territorial jurisdiction and the causes of action arose here.

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: The condition of the electrical wiring in the Office Bedroom, and the resulting absence of electricity there, constitutes a serious interference with the livability and habitability of the Premises, in violation of the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including but not limited to 105 C.M.R. 410.351, 410.352, and 410.750 (requiring safe and adequate electrical service in residential dwellings).

105 C.M.R. 410.351.proposition: The condition of the electrical wiring in the Office Bedroom, and the resulting absence of electricity there, constitutes a serious interference with the livability and habitability of the Premises, in violation of the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including but not limited to 105 C.M.R. 410.351, 410.352, and 410.750 (requiring safe and adequate electrical service in residential dwellings).

105 C.M.R. 410.352.proposition: The condition of the electrical wiring in the Office Bedroom, and the resulting absence of electricity there, constitutes a serious interference with the livability and habitability of the Premises, in violation of the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including but not limited to 105 C.M.R. 410.351, 410.352, and 410.750 (requiring safe and adequate electrical service in residential dwellings).

105 C.M.R. 410.750.proposition: The condition of the electrical wiring in the Office Bedroom, and the resulting absence of electricity there, constitutes a serious interference with the livability and habitability of the Premises, in violation of the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including but not limited to 105 C.M.R. 410.351, 410.352, and 410.750 (requiring safe and adequate electrical service in residential dwellings).

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 96\u2013.proposition: The statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 is read into every residential tenancy in Massachusetts, whether or not expressly stated in the lease.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 96\u2013.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that "[e]very tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant" of quiet enjoyment and then immediately ties that common-law covenant to G.L. c. 186, § 14. The court treats quiet enjoyment as an implied covenant inherent in all tenancies, not dependent on express lease language, and reads the statutory protection as incorporating that implied covenant. This directly supports the proposition that the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under § 14 is read into every residential tenancy in Massachusetts whether or not stated in the lease.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 96\u2013.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy. … When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’ … it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 281–82 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: The statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 is read into every residential tenancy in Massachusetts, whether or not expressly stated in the lease.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, applies it to the facts, and notes that the defendant "covenant[ed] that the plaintiffs' right to quiet enjoyment shall not be interfered with." However, the court does not state or hold that § 14 is read into every residential tenancy regardless of lease language; it simply applies § 14 where a covenant existed and explains its scope and breach standard. There is no explicit statement that the statutory covenant is implied in all residential tenancies, so the case does not clearly support that broader proposition.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 186, § 14, provides, in relevant part, that "any lessor or landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant" shall be punished by a fine or imprisonment, and also shall be subject to liability to the tenant for damages arising from the interference. ... If the defendant has taken no action or inadequate action, despite covenanting that the plaintiffs' right to quiet enjoyment shall not be interfered with, then the plaintiffs will be entitled to judgment, appropriate injunctive relief, costs and reasonable attorney's fees. See G. L. c. 186, § 14.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.proposition: A landlord’s negligent or intentional failure to correct serious defects in an apartment, especially those affecting habitability and use, after notice, constitutes an unlawful interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.support_reasoning: The case directly holds that a landlord can breach the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment by conduct that is the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted to be done, even without an intent to deprive the tenant. The court affirms that where serious interferences with habitability and use (here, extreme noise) persist after notice and the landlord has the ability to correct them but does not do so effectively, the landlord may not collect rent because the premises are not reasonably habitable, which fits within G.L. c. 186, § 14’s quiet enjoyment framework.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.relevant_excerpt: There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done... Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.proposition: A landlord’s negligent or intentional failure to correct serious defects in an apartment, especially those affecting habitability and use, after notice, constitutes an unlawful interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses what level of landlord fault is required for liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and explicitly reaffirms that a landlord’s negligent failure to repair known defects in leased premises can constitute a violation of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment. Although the specific defect here is lead paint, the court cites and endorses prior cases holding that failure to correct serious, habitability-related defects after notice is an interference with quiet enjoyment. The case’s holding that at least negligence plus notice (or reason to know) and failure to act are required directly supports the proposition’s statement of the standard.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.relevant_excerpt: “Twelve years later, in Cruz Mgt. Co. v. Thomas, supra, we rejected a claim that a violation of G. L. c. 186, § 14, could be imposed only if it were proved that a landlord was reckless in disregarding his tenant’s rights, and we concluded that negligent conduct, conduct involving ‘some degree of fault,’ by a landlord could support the imposition of liability under § 14. Id. at 789. We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’”

Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 473, 477–80 (2004)
Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious and substantial interference with the use and enjoyment of the premises, including conditions that render parts of the premises effectively unusable.
Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion expressly defines the covenant of quiet enjoyment as protecting tenants from “serious interferences with their tenancies” and from acts or omissions that “impair the value of the leased premises.” It then applies that standard to a longstanding ventilation defect that made the bathroom effectively unusable and dangerous, holding that these conditions constituted a serious interference and substantial impairment of the character and value of the premises. This directly supports the proposition that quiet enjoyment covers serious, substantial interferences including conditions rendering parts of the premises effectively unusable.
Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “The implied covenant of quiet enjoyment guarantees tenants the right to be free from ‘serious’ interferences with their tenancies. See G. L. c. 186, § 14… A landlord violates G. L. c. 186, § 14, when its ‘acts or omissions impair the value of the leased premises.’ … Because of the defective ventilation, the tenants were forced to keep the bathroom door shut and to run the fan continuously, a dangerous situation which led to a fire in the apartment.… we think that the judge was required to find a serious interference with the tenancy and substantial impairment of the character and value of the leased premises.”}

Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien, 363 Mass. 359.proposition: A landlord may be liable under G.L. c. 186, § 14 when defective conditions violate the State Sanitary Code or materially impair the character and value of the leased premises for residential purposes.
Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien, 363 Mass. 359.case_name: Board of Appeals of Hanover v. Housing Appeals Comm.
Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien, 363 Mass. 359.support_reasoning: This opinion is about G.L. c. 40B (the Anti-Snob Zoning Act) and the power of zoning boards and the Housing Appeals Committee to override local zoning to permit low- and moderate-income housing. It does not interpret G.L. c. 186, § 14, nor does it concern landlord-tenant liability, defective conditions, the State Sanitary Code, or impairment of the character and value of leased premises. Therefore it cannot be authority for landlord liability under c. 186, § 14 based on sanitary code violations or material impairment of residential premises.
Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien, 363 Mass. 359.relevant_excerpt: We have often stated that a construction of a statute which would completely negate legislative intent should be avoided. ... Therefore, we hold that c. 774 confers on boards of appeals and the Housing Appeals Committee the power to override local “requirements and regulations,” including zoning ordinances or by-laws, which are not “consistent with local needs.”

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 200–03 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: A landlord may be liable under G.L. c. 186, § 14 when defective conditions violate the State Sanitary Code or materially impair the character and value of the leased premises for residential purposes.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The case is about common-law breach of the implied warranty of habitability and rent abatement; it does not interpret or apply G.L. c. 186, § 14. While the opinion discusses State Sanitary Code violations as benchmarks for habitability and notes that a dwelling with substantial Sanitary Code violations is not habitable, it never mentions § 14 or holds that a landlord is liable under that statute based on such defects. Thus it cannot be cited as direct authority for liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. The essential objective of the warranty is to make sure that the tenant receives what she is paying for. … In the latter instance, the landlord must comply at least with minimum standards prescribed by the State building and sanitary codes. Whether the scope of the warranty is broader is an open question.” (379 Mass. at 201–02).

Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.raw_text: Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761–62 (1979)
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.proposition: The measure of damages for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment includes actual and consequential damages, which may encompass loss of use and enjoyment, diminution in rental value, and out‑of‑pocket expenses incurred to mitigate or cope with the defective conditions.
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 and states that where there is a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, the statute “expands the measure of damages to include all ‘actual and consequential damages.’” It then identifies the tenant’s “actual damages” as including both diminution in the value of the leasehold and damage to personal property, which are classic consequential losses. While it does not list every conceivable category (like mitigation expenses) by name, the reasoning clearly endorses recovery of actual and consequential damages such as loss of use/enjoyment (via diminished rental value) and out‑of‑pocket property losses arising from the defective condition.
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 provides that a lessor who commits any act in violation of that section (including interference ‘with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises’) shall ‘be liable for actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater….’ … It is clear that the plaintiff’s actual damages exceeded three times her monthly rent of $47. Her actual damages included the diminution of the value of the leasehold due to the breach of the implied warranty of habitability, as well as the damage to her personal property.… Section 14 of G. L. c. 186 expands the measure of damages to include all ‘actual and consequential damages’ where, as here, there has been a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”
